name: The IKEA Effect
the-point: People value products more if they had a hand in building them themselves.

name: Coca-Cola Origins
the-point: Coca-Cola was originally marketed as a patent medicine to cure headaches and exhaustion.

name: The 80/20 Rule
the-point: 80% of a company's revenue usually comes from just 20% of its customers.

name: Loss Leaders
the-point: Costco loses money on every rotisserie chicken it sells just to get you in the door.

name: Bitcoin Pizza
the-point: The first real-world Bitcoin transaction was 10,000 BTC for two pizzas (now worth hundreds of millions).

name: Brand Loyalty
the-point: Is it better for a brand to be loved by some and hated by others, or 'just okay' to everyone?

name: The Sandwich Method
the-point: Giving feedback by 'sandwiching' a critique between two compliments makes it more effective.

name: McDonald's Real Estate
the-point: McDonald's isn't a burger company; it is one of the world's largest real estate companies.

name: Quiet Quitting
the-point: Is 'quiet quitting' a sign of poor work ethic or a healthy boundary against burnout?

name: Planned Obsolescence
the-point: Do companies intentionally make products break sooner so you have to buy new ones?

name: Personal Branding
the-point: In the future, will your personal reputation (social score) be more important than your resume?

name: Luxury Pricing
the-point: Luxury brands often destroy unsold inventory rather than selling it at a discount to keep 'exclusivity'.

name: Remote Work
the-point: Can a company maintain a strong culture if nobody ever meets in person?

name: Side Hustles
the-point: Should everyone have a second source of income in the AI era?

name: The Pet Rock
the-point: The man who invented the Pet Rock became a millionaire by selling literal stones in boxes.

name: Founder's Trap
the-point: Why do the founders of billion-dollar companies often get fired by their own boards?

name: Stock Market Luck
the-point: A blindfolded monkey throwing darts at a newspaper can often pick stocks better than professional traders.

name: Subscription Fatigue
the-point: Will we eventually reach a point where we own nothing and subscribe to everything (furniture, clothes, cars)?

name: Gamification
the-point: Is it ethical for apps like Duolingo or Robinhood to use 'game mechanics' to keep us addicted?

name: Negotiation Power
the-point: The person who speaks first in a negotiation usually loses the 'anchor' advantage.

name: Universal Basic Income
the-point: If everyone got $1,000 a month for free, would prices just go up to match it?

name: Apple’s Cash
the-point: Apple often has more cash on hand than the entire US government treasury.

name: The First Ad
the-point: The first TV commercial ever was for Bulova watches and cost only $9 to air.

name: Work-Life Balance
the-point: Is 'Work-Life Balance' a lie? Should we be aiming for 'Work-Life Integration' instead?

name: The Uncanny Valley
the-point: Why do we feel 'creeped out' by robots that look almost—but not quite—human?
